Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Measurement and Modeling of Air Entrainment and Ash Distribution in Weak Volcanic Plumes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2010 eruption of Eyjafjallaj√∂kull volcano in Iceland resulted in weeks of air traffic disruption and more than a billion dollars of economic losses. The disruption was exacerbated by limitations in the accuracy of models used to forecast the size, location, and ash concentration of the cloud. The pre-2010 airline industry policy was to avoid any volcanic ash during flight, and existing models predicted that the plume covered much of Europe. This has provided a new challenge to forecasters, as the rate that ash is fed into the cloud cannot be accurately estimated in complex flow situations. This rate is usually determined from the height of the plume above the volcano, but it can vary significantly due to many factors, including eruptive conditions, atmospheric properties, and local wind speeds. Hence, there is a vital need to develop improved models for realistic conditions.

Traditional plume models assume flow in a calm atmosphere, but plumes are significantly modified by perpendicular cross flows with varying scales of turbulence. While cross flow has been considered in some models, the accuracy is still quite crude. This study will develop an improved understanding of volcanic plumes in a stratified cross flow, which will be used to aid in forecasting the dispersal of hazardous ash clouds. Advanced experimental techniques will be used to measure the flow in a laboratory scale plume. These results will be incorporated directly into a state-of-the-art analytical model, which will more accurately quantify the ash density distribution for volcanic scales. In addition, this research will be presented to the broad public audience through small-scale, hands-on laboratory demonstrations at the Oregon Museum of Science and Industry (OMSI).

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2010, the relatively small, remote volcano Eyjafjallajökull erupted, generating an ash cloud that covered much of Europe for several days.  Air traffic was curtailed, costing billions of dollars of economic losses.  The emergency was exacerbated by unclear forecasts of the ash density, which indicated hazardous conditions even when the ash could not be clearly seen.  Forecast accuracy was limited by the estimate of the mass of material erupted, which is typically determined through rapid field observations of volcanic plume height and eruption duration.  This information can be used in models that simulate the plume growth, but unfortunately these models are most accurate in a calm atmosphere.  With significant cross wind and atmospheric variation, the model accuracy is relatively crude, limiting the ability to effectively make forecasts.

To address these issues, a team from Washington State University (WSU), Portland State University (PSU), and the USGS Cascades Volcano Observatory (CVO) was assembled to study plumes in cross flow.  Over the past three years, the team conducted high-accuracy, laser-based particle image velocimetry (PIV) experiments to improve the accuracy of flow measurements, and these were integrated into state-of-the-art analytical models.  In the first two phases of the study, wind tunnel experiments were used to measure plumes in cross flow and buoyant conditions, respectively.  In the third phase, these results were used to improve the one-dimensional model Plumeria, and its effectiveness was examined for several full-scale eruptions.  

At WSU, experiments were conducted in the first phase of the research, which focused on how cross flow affected the inflow of atmospheric air, or “entrainment”, into a jet.  When the jet was buoyant, the relative inflow was reduced, and it approached a constant magnitude much faster than with air jets.  In addition, there was a distinct difference at lower speeds, with significantly higher inflow just as the jet began transitioning to turbulent conditions.  This latter behavior is largely neglected in plume modeling, but it may influence geological flows in fumaroles and springs.

The second phase of the study was primarily conducted at PSU, examining cross flow with density variation using PIV measurements.  The results of the first two phases were integrated during the third phase at WSU and CVO, which focused on modeling.  This analysis showed that there are optimal values that estimate the inflow, which accurately predict the experimentally-measured jet trajectories using the one-dimensional model Plumeria.  At a specific cross wind speed, there is a range of these values that produces nearly the same prediction, which helps explain why different models have performed similarly.  However, nearly all cross wind speeds overlap at a single set of values, which was then used in an improved Plumeria model.  This modified version was used to examine several historic eruptions, and estimates of the plume height agreed with field data to within 3 km.  Even better accuracy was found in strong eruptions.  The model also predicted the trajectory from Eyjafjallajökull accurately.

Throughout the study, the team performed educational outreach at the Oregon Museum of Science & Industry (OMSI), presenting the findings to the general public.  We developed an interactive, hands-on activity on volcanic plumes in cross flow, which is presented at OMSI periodically.  This outreach has been conducted multiple times per year by the principal investigators, a graduate student, and the youth-oriented OMSI Teen Science Alliance, reaching over 1000 guests of varying age and educational background.  The demonstration has also been converted into a permanent activity at the museum.  

Finally, the project results have been disseminated to the scientific community through a series of journal articles and conference presentations.  At present, there is one published journal article, two more in review, and three more in final preparation for review.  A total of 10 conference presentations have been given at geophysical and engineering conferences, with 2 more submitted for future events.  One graduate student at WSU wrote a thesis on this work as part of his Masters program.
